Award.AwardTitle: The Mechanics of Lung Development in Three Different Species

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Morphogenesis is the process by which simple tissues fold into the complex shapes of mature organs, such as the branching airways of the lung. This tissue folding is caused by patterns of mechanical forces (pushing and pulling the tissue) that are induced by the expression of different genes throughout the tissue. The final shapes of the lungs of mammals, birds, and reptiles are vastly different, suggesting that the mechanical forces and genes expressed are different as well. This award supports fundamental research to define the gene expression changes and mechanical forces that fold the airways of the lungs in three different species (mouse, chicken, and alligator). Understanding what is unique and what is conserved between lungs of different species will provide insight into how different organs evolved over time. Additionally, being able to manipulate the expression of genes to control organ development is critical for tissue engineering applications for the biomedical and healthcare industries. Results from this research will therefore have economic and societal benefits for the United States. This research combines techniques and insights from several disciplines, including developmental biology, mechanobiology, and biomedical engineering. This interdisciplinary approach will help broaden the participation of underrepresented minority groups (at the undergraduate and high school levels) and enhance outreach interactions with the lay population.

Mammals, birds, and reptiles have evolved different anatomical strategies for the conduction and diffusion of air through the lungs, which must result from differences in airway morphogenesis in the embryo. The objective of this project is to define and quantify these evolutionary morphogenetic differences. The research team will use three-dimensional traction force microscopy, real time confocal imaging, and continuum mechanical modeling to quantify the forces exerted during morphogenesis of the distinct airway architectures of embryonic mice, chicks, and alligators. In parallel, high-throughput gene expression analysis will be conducted for each morphogenetic movement in each species. These analyses will reveal the distinct gene expression changes that control mechanical forces within the epithelium as it folds lateral branches (mammals and birds), bifurcating branches (mammals and reptiles), and anastomosing airways (birds and reptiles). This research adopts for the first time the principles of mechanobiology within the framework of evolutionary developmental biology to create a comprehensive physical description of tissue morphogenesis, and will uncover the basic mechanical differences underlying lung development in different species.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In Specific Aim 1, we proposed to define the mechanical forces that underlie airway branching morphogenesis in mammals, birds, and reptiles. This would be accomplished by combining real-time imaging with traction force microscopy, to (Aim 1a) visualize cytoskeletal and cell shape changes that drive lateral branching, terminal bifurcations, and airway anastomses and to define (Aim 1b) and model (Aim 1c) the physical forces that drive lateral branching, terminal bifurcation, and airway anastomosis. In Specific Aim 2, we proposed to define the molecular signals that direct mechanical forces during branching morphogenesis of the airways in lungs from mammals, birds, and reptiles. This would be

accomplished by (Aim 2a) focusing on candidate signaling pathways, (Aim 2b) using RNA-Seq to define gene expression changes, and (Aim 2c) manipulating signaling pathways to control branching de novo.

 

We have found that in the mouse lung, both terminal bifurcation and lateral branching are driven by patterned differentiation of airway smooth muscle. The airway smooth muscle tissue was previously thought to play no functional role in normal lung development; our data show that this tissue is absolutely essential for formation of the mammalian lung. Differentiation of airway smooth muscle is promoted by mechanical forces from fluid pressure within the lumen of the airways. We have identified one putative molecular signal from pressure using RNA-sequencing analysis, and are exploring its functional role in future work.

 

In contrast, we have found that lateral branching occurs independently of airway smooth muscle in the developing chicken lung. In this organ, new branches form via active contraction of the cells that line the airways. However, airway smooth muscle begins to appear at later stages of development, where it may play a role of fusion of the airways (anastomosis). We are currently investigating how smooth muscle differentiation is controlled in the avian lung.

 

We set up a colony of anole lizards as our model reptile and have created the first system to stage their lung development. Surprisingly, we found that airway smooth muscle appears early during the morphogenesis of the anole lung, and coalesces into a pattern that directs morphogenesis of the lung itself. These data suggest an evolutionarily conserved role for airway smooth muscle in lung development.

 

This project has supported the research training of ten undergraduate senior thesis students. The project has also supported the training of one PhD student, who has learned how to mentor undergraduates during the process.
